awd_titl_txt: Rare Earth Elements Tracing Crustal Evolution Through Time: A Detrital Zircon Study
awd_abstract_narration:
Multiple recent lines of evidence suggest that the onset of modern-like plate tectonic processes started rather abruptly in the Archean (about 3 billion years ago) and that tectonically, the Earth has evolved through several distinctive dynamic stages. The overarching question here is to test the hypothesis of several step-like changes in the tectono-magmatic evolution of the Earth. Such change should be reflected in the geochemical composition of intermediate and felsic igneous rocks - the basic building blocks of continental masses. If this did happen, can we better constrain the age of that change, was it sudden or gradual? Unraveling tectonics stages and transitions between them on our dynamic planet has important implications for our overall understanding of resource distribution as well as feedbacks with other evolutionary processes in the mineral and biologic realms.  

In the project, the researchers will use detrital zircon U-Pb ages and trace elemental concentrations (with a focus on the rare earth elements) on grains from sediments and sedimentary rocks that satisfy the following conditions: (1) are draining sizable segments of the continental mass, and (2) contain zircons encompassing large geologic time intervals, especially from the Precambrian. The age range target will especially focus on the Hadean, Archean and Proterozoic area. Recent work shows that whole rock geochemical parameters measured on young igneous rocks correlate positively with crustal thickness globally and regionally. La/Yb and other trace elemental ratios are calibrated against crustal thickness on intermediate igneous rocks from modern subduction systems and have been used to show variations in crustal thickness over time in a few Phanerozoic orogenic regions. The implied variation in crustal thickness is consistent with the tens of million years cyclicity of crustal thickness in continental areas being affected by modern plate tectonics and is also indicative of the fact that the deepest parts of the continental crust (regardless of its thickness) are the factories of differentiation leading to the diversity of intermediate igneous rocks found in subduction and collision systems.

por.por_cntn:
We have pioneered a new technique that allows us to measure by laser ablation techniques simultaneously ages and elemental by laser ablation techniques on the mineral zircon. Zircon is an accessory silicate of zirconium that is known for being extremely resistant to destruction at the surface of the earth and thus is present in small amounts in all sedimentary rocks. These crystals form from granitic magmas but then get recycled into sandstones and other sedimentary materials. Zircons of a variety of ages are found in the sedimentary archive and when major rivers draining large areas of the continental crust are sampled, they usually provide a wealth of zircons of a large range of ages. It is the fastest way to get a grip on materials of varied origins and ages of the continental crust. Trace elements that we measure in these zircons contain information about the origin of igneous rocks (usually granitoids) from which they crystallized. We studied some major continental rivers as well as some ancient sandstones in order to get a complete record of zircon ages in the sedimentary archive. We then measured thousands of these zircons to obtain their age and chemistry and ultimately address how did the formation of granites change over time since the Earth’s earliest days (Hadean, 4.3 billion years, or Ga) to present. We determined that there is relatively little change over time in the temperature and other physical conditions of making granites (and continental crust). The continental crust may have been governed by different processes driving magmatism over time, but the products were always rather similar. However, some distinct moments in time (e.g., 0.6 Ga) were characterized by unusually thick crust globally and demand further study. These findings were made in a highly collaborative team of graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs and were disseminated at national and international meetings and in high impact scholarly journals. We have incorporated these findings in our graduate courses as well as in lecture series presented in high schools nationally and internationally to promote geosciences. The highlight papers published from this study are Balica et al. (2020, Earth and Planetary Science Letters) and Ducea et al., (2021, Earth Science Reviews). The technique itself is available today for all interested users that gather their data at the Arizona Laserchron NSF-funded national facility. The project has spearheaded new ways of measuring titanite and apatite concomitantly with ages by similar tools (high resolution, single collector ICP-MS).
